content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple (approximately 8-9) fragments of fibrofatty tissue, most of which are identifiable as lymph nodes. Many of these nodes appear enlarged and contain large, dense, basophilic (dark purple) areas, which are highly suspicious for metastatic tumor involvement. The overall impression is of a case with multiple positive lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, it is crucial to examine every single lymph node submitted to accurately stage the cancer. The green box is located on one of the smaller lymph nodes in the lower-left quadrant. I am zooming into this specific area as part of a systematic review of all potential lymph nodes. This node, despite its smaller size, also shows a suspicious dark purple area that needs high-magnification assessment to confirm or rule out the presence of metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol is to systematically examine every piece of tissue to identify all lymph nodes for accurate cancer staging (N stage). The area in the green box contains another one of these discrete, dark nodules, consistent with a lymph node. Although smaller than some others, it is suspicious for metastasis. I am zooming into this specific lymph node (approximately the 7th or 8th node, counting from the top) to confirm its nature and assess for the presence of metastatic tumor. Examining the periphery first, as indicated by the zoom, is also crucial for evaluating potential extranodal extension (tumor spreading beyond the lymph node capsule). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to assess each lymph node for the presence of metastasis. I would systematically examine every node. The selected area, which is the second lymph node from the top on the left side, is chosen for initial evaluation. Its large size and solid, dark appearance at low power are suspicious for effacement of the normal lymph node architecture by a tumor. Zooming in is essential to confirm if it is a lymph node and to search for atypical, non-lymphoid cells that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue that could be a lymph node. The area indicated by the green box is the first lymph node at the top-left corner. It contains a well-defined, densely cellular, dark purple area that is a region of interest. It is crucial to zoom in on such areas to determine if the cellularity is due to a reactive lymphoid population or an infiltrate of metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for these tissue sections is to identify any lymph nodes containing metastatic tumor cells (positive nodes). I would systematically examine every piece of tissue on the slide. The green box is placed on the second lymph node from the top-left. I am zooming into this specific area because it contains a well-demarcated, dark basophilic region that needs to be assessed at higher magnification to determine if it is a benign reactive process (like follicular hyperplasia) or a metastatic tumor deposit. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to assess every lymph node for the presence of metastasis. I would systematically examine each one. The selected area is one of the lymph nodes (the first one from the top left) that clearly shows a large, dark, abnormal-looking infiltrate. Zooming in is necessary to examine the cellular morphology of this infiltrate at high power to confirm whether it is metastatic carcinoma, a reactive process, or another pathology. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would systematically examine every piece of tissue that looks like a lymph node to confirm the presence and extent of metastasis. The selected area is one of these suspicious lymph nodes. The zoom is necessary to evaluate the cellular and architectural features at high magnification to definitively identify malignant cells and distinguish them from reactive lymphoid tissue. This specific node, located in the central part of the slide, shows a clear dark infiltrate that requires confirmation as metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located within the largest, most centrally located lymph node on the slide. At low magnification, this node contains a significant, well-demarcated basophilic infiltrate that is highly suggestive of a metastatic deposit. A high-power view is necessary to examine the cytology of the cells (e.g., look for atypia, gland formation) and confirm that this is metastatic carcinoma rather than a reactive lymphoid process or lymphoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it contains a large, well-defined vessel located immediately adjacent to a lymph node that appears to be involved by tumor. A critical part of staging colorectal cancer is to assess for lymphovascular invasion (LVI), particularly extramural venous invasion (EMVI). Examining this vessel allows me to check if tumor cells are present within its lumen or invading its wall, which is a significant adverse prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. This is one of the suspected positive lymph nodes, located in the lower right portion of the slide. I am zooming into the periphery of this node, specifically at the interface between the dense tumor infiltrate and the surrounding adipose tissue. The primary reason is to assess for the presence of extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the perinodal fat. ENE is a critical prognostic factor and needs to be evaluated at high magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to systematically evaluate each potential lymph node for the presence of metastasis. The selected fragment, located in the upper right portion of the slide, is clearly a lymph node structure containing a prominent dark, cellular region. High-magnification examination is necessary to confirm whether this represents metastatic carcinoma by identifying malignant glandular cells, as opposed to a reactive lymphoid process. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue on the slide to identify all lymph nodes and assess them for metastasis. The zoomed-in area corresponds to the first lymph node from the top on the left side. This node appears almost entirely replaced by a dark, cellular infiltrate, making it a high-priority area to examine closely to confirm the presence and characteristics of the metastatic tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, it is critical to examine every single piece of tissue that could be a lymph node to accurately determine the N stage. The area indicated by the green box is one of these potential lymph nodes. Although it is smaller than some of the other fragments, it contains a distinct basophilic focus that must be evaluated at high magnification to determine if it is reactive lymphoid tissue or a metastatic deposit. This is part of a systematic review of all submitted lymph nodes. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic evaluation of all potential lymph nodes. This specific tissue fragment, located in the lower right quadrant, contains a large, densely cellular node that is highly suspicious for metastasis. The purpose of zooming in is to confirm the presence of metastatic carcinoma, assess the extent of nodal involvement (i.e., how much of the node is replaced by tumor), and, critically, to evaluate the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding adipose tissue for any evidence of extranodal extension (tumor cells breaching the lymph node capsule). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the normal lymphoid architecture is almost completely replaced by a dense infiltrate of malignant cells. These cells are arranged in solid sheets and poorly-formed glandular structures. They exhibit pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. At the bottom of the image, the tumor cells can be seen infiltrating the perinodal adipose tissue (the large white circular spaces). My definitive impression is a positive lymph node, completely replaced by metastatic adenocarcinoma with evidence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see predominantly mature adipose tissue, characterized by large, clear adipocytes. There are also some small, irregular clusters of basophilic cells (lymphocytes or possibly tumor cells) within the fatty tissue. This view appears to be focused on the perinodal fat, right at the edge of the main lymph node structure. My impression is that I am evaluating the tissue immediately surrounding a lymph node. The presence of these small cell clusters requires closer inspection to differentiate between a reactive inflammatory infiltrate and extranodal extension of a tumor. The next step would be to pan into the main body of the node to assess it for metastatic disease.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a lymph node that is heavily infiltrated by a malignant tumor. The background consists of dense sheets of small, dark lymphocytes, characteristic of a lymph node. However, scattered and clustered throughout are irregular glands composed of atypical epithelial cells. These malignant cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. The formation of these back-to-back, poorly-formed glands is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, unequivocally containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense and monotonous population of small, round cells with scant cytoplasm and dark nuclei. These features are characteristic of lymphocytes. I do not see any definite malignant features such as glandular formation, nests of atypical epithelial cells, large pleomorphic nuclei, or prominent nucleoli that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression of this specific area is that it represents a benign, reactive lymph node or a portion of one. The dense appearance from the thumbnail is due to a packed population of lymphocytes, not tumor.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see an interface between mature adipose tissue (large, white, circular cells) and a dense, sheet-like proliferation of cells. These cells are small, round, and have dark nuclei with scant cytoplasm, which is morphologically consistent with lymphocytes. I do not see the typical features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as formation of irregular glands, large pleomorphic cells with vesicular chromatin, or prominent nucleoli. Therefore, my impression of this specific area is that it represents a dense aggregate of benign lymphocytes within the lymph node, likely part of the normal cortex or a reactive follicle. This area appears negative for metastasis, and I would proceed to scan the rest of this node and the other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is effaced by a dense, monotonous sheet of small, round, darkly staining cells with scant cytoplasm. This infiltrate is expanding and pushing into the surrounding adipose tissue. While the initial suspicion from the thumbnail was metastatic colorectal cancer, the high-power view reveals cellular features more consistent with a lymphoid malignancy. The cells lack the glandular formation, pleomorphism, and eosinophilic cytoplasm typical of colorectal adenocarcinoma. Instead, this morphology is highly characteristic of a low-grade B-cell lymphoma, such as Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma/Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (SLL/CLL). This is a significant incidental finding, as this lymph node is involved by lymphoma, not metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view reveals a dense infiltration by malignant epithelial cells. The cells are arranged in poorly formed, crowded glands and solid sheets, characteristic of adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells exhibit significant nuclear atypia, including enlargement, irregular nuclear contours, and hyperchromasia. These malignant cells are seen infiltrating and replacing the normal lymph node parenchyma and extending into the surrounding adipose tissue (the large, clear, circular spaces). My impression is that this is unequivocally metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node, confirming it as a positive node.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense, monotonous sheet of malignant cells with dark, hyperchromatic, and irregular nuclei, and scant cytoplasm. The normal architecture of the lymph node is completely effaced and replaced by this tumor infiltrate. There are also scattered dark pigment deposits, likely anthracotic pigment or hemosiderin, which can be seen in lymph nodes. The overall impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma, likely from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 9. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows a cross-section of a large, thick-walled blood vessel, consistent with a vein. The vessel is surrounded by mature adipose tissue. There are also aggregates of lymphocytes (small, dark purple cells) in the surrounding fat, which are part of the adjacent lymph node tissue. In this specific field of view, the vessel lumen is clear and there is no evidence of tumor cells within the vessel or invading its wall. My impression is that this is a large vein without evidence of invasion in this particular frame, but I would continue to examine the entire circumference of this vessel and other vessels in the vicinity.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I can clearly see a sheet-like and nested infiltrate of malignant epithelial cells with large, dark nuclei and irregular shapes, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. These malignant cells are directly infiltrating into the adjacent mature adipose tissue. There is no discernible fibrous lymph node capsule separating the tumor from the fat. This confirms the presence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can see a clear demarcation between two types of tissue. On the left, there is residual lymph node tissue characterized by a dense population of small, dark lymphocytes, intermixed with numerous large, clear fat cells (adipocytes). On the right, there are cohesive nests and sheets of larger, pleomorphic cells with more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and irregular, vesicular nuclei. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, partially replaced by metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal architecture of the lymph node is almost completely effaced. It is replaced by a dense infiltrate of malignant cells with large, dark, irregular nuclei (hyperchromatic and pleomorphic). The cells are arranged in poorly-formed, back-to-back glandular structures, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. Importantly, I see nests of these malignant cells infiltrating directly into the surrounding adipose tissue (fat cells). My impression is a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma with clear evidence of extranodal extension.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense, diffuse sheet of small, round, blue cells with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The tissue is surrounded by mature adipose tissue. I do not see any definite features of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as the formation of glands, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or extracellular mucin. My impression of this specific field of view is that it is a lymph node composed of lymphoid tissue, and it appears to be negative for metastasis. The entire node and all other nodes on the slide would need to be examined to make a final determination.
This is ROI 14 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view shows a lymph node that is largely effaced by a dense, solid sheet of malignant cells with large, hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. This tumor mass is seen directly infiltrating the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue on the left side of the view. The normal lymph node architecture is almost completely replaced. The clear evidence of tumor cells within the adjacent fatty tissue confirms the presence of extranodal extension. My impression is a positive lymph node with extensive metastatic carcinoma and definite extranodal extension.
